messageBody:
On 6/1/06, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
>
> I disagree that there is a limited responsibility. A developer
> should not release code that they haven't tested. They should not
> release a line of code that they have not tested. Every line, every
> statement, every condition should be tested before the developer
> releases the code. It seems to me that's a minimum professional
> standard. Releasing code that you have not thoroughly tested is,
> simply, unprofessional.


That's a bit extreme, but not contradictory with what I said earlier.

I can't really think of any project I worked on where I knew deep inside
that 100% of the code I or my colleagues wrote was tested. It's a fact of
life: we never ship the product we want, and at some point, we need to draw
the line.

Developers need to test their code, but I'm a bit more lenient on "how" they
do it. Ideally, I'd like them to use TDD, but if they can make a reasonable
case for not doing TDD, I'll be fine with it as long as they provide
reasonable tests.

There is also another aspect that is often overlooked in the kind of
discussion we're having right now: QA departments.

Open source projects are ideal Petri dishes: if the developers are the
bleeding edge kind, they will typically write code and supply 100% of the
tests. Things are quite different in the industry and it's very common to
see engineering and QA share the load of testing. When you start factoring
this in, the impact of TDD becomes harder to quantify.

At the very least, I expect developers to write "passing" tests for their
code, but after this, it's quite common to see these tests passed along to
QA which will expand on them and bring their own mindset and experience.

I have been fortunate to work with very talented QA engineers who were
absolutely brilliant at improving the tests initially supplied by the
developers, and obviously, TDD is quite irrelevant for these QA departments
since the code has already been written.

--
Cédric
